channel.title: New HDD
channel.description: I'm considering getting a larger hard drive because the one I use now was originally meant for gaming, and is only 80 gigs. I want to get a 120 gig to store all of my photoshop, c4d, and after effects files, large torrents etc. So basically, I wanted to know if I could install Linux onto my new drive, and still be able to access the files on my 120gig while I am running WinXP on my 80gig. Or if its even possible at all. I've never had two HDDs at once, so I don't really know much about it.

item.title: New HDD
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Exception:

How DO you access NTFS under Linux!? I have never been able to, because as far as I know Microsoft hasn’t released any decent documentation of how it works, so Linux drivers can’t be developed.

There has been NTFS drivers for ages. Install the relevant NTFS package for your distro and then add the partition to /etc/fstab with the type “ntfs”. Google is your friend if you want a detailed tutorial.

I believe Linux can access NTFS (you need root), but Windows doesn’t make sense of Linux’s file sytem. You could dual boot from two HDD, I believe. If you set up a second FAT partition, both Windows and Linux can access it.
